chapter.htmlHeader: What screening tests are used in the NHS bowel screening programme?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• The presence of blood in stools is an indicator of pre-malignant and malignant bowel lesions. As blood in stools may not be visible, faecal occult blood testing is used as a primary screening tool to detect its presence.
    • Colonoscopy (the definitive diagnostic investigation for bowel cancer) is unsuitable as a primary screening test because it is:
      • Associated with a small but significant risk of complications (such as perforation) and mortality.
      • Requires specially trained clinical staff to carry it out.
      • Invasive and therefore unlikely to be acceptable to the population.
  • Faecal occult blood tests used in the NHS bowel cancer screening programme include:
    • Guaiac faecal occult blood testing (gFOBt).
    • Faecal immunochemical testing (FIT) — in 2016 the UK National Screening Committee (UK NSC) recommended replacing gFOBt with FIT as the primary test used in the NHS bowel cancer screening programme as FIT is:
      • Easier to use and may increase uptake of screening — only one stool sample from a single bowel motion is required compared to 2 samples from 3 different motions needed for gFOBt.
      • More sensitive — FIT can detect a much lower concentration of blood in the faeces (0.02 mg Hb/g) compared to gFOBt (0.6 mg Hb/g).
      • More specific — gFOBt is not specific for colonic bleeding, it can be falsely positive in the presence of dietary components (such as red meat) or upper gastrointestinal irritation (for example due to medication).
  • In addition to faecal occult blood screening, one-off flexible sigmoidoscopy (Bowelscope) screening was introduced to areas of England in 2013 to people aged 55 years.
    • If polyps are identified during sigmoidoscopy, these are biopsied and the rest of the bowel is examined by colonoscopy.

[UK NSC, 2016; Inadomi, 2017; Koo, 2017; NHS Health Scotland, 2017; NICE, 2017; PHE, 2018; UK National Screening Committee, 2018; Cancer Research UK, 2019e]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What is the faecal immunochemical test (FIT).
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The faecal immunochemical test (FIT)
    • FIT detects small amounts of blood in stool samples using antibodies specific to human haemoglobin. It is less likely to detect globin from upper gastrointestinal bleeding than guaiac-based tests as it targets the globin component of haemoglobin, which degrades as it passes through the gut.
    • FIT for screening is quantitative and the threshold for an abnormal result is set locally. For further information see the sections on the NHS bowel cancer screening programme in England, Scotland and Wales.
  • The screening process
    • An invitation letter (including information on possible benefits and risks of screening) followed by a FIT test kit is sent to the participants home address.
    • Participants unscrew the cap of the test, dip the end of the stick into a single bowel motion, replace the stick in the tube, screw the lid shut and return the sample in the prepaid envelope provided.
    • Results are sent by letter to the person's home address within 2 weeks of the lab receiving the completed kit.
    • The person's GP is informed of the result electronically.

[NICE, 2017; UK NSC, 2016; PHE, 2018; Cancer Research UK, 2019c]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What is the guaiac faecal occult blood test (gFOBt)?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The guaiac faecal occult blood test (gFOBt)
    • The gFOBt contains guaiac which reacts with pseudoperoxidase in haem. This changes the colour of the sample on subsequent laboratory analysis if blood is present in the stool.
  • The screening process
    • An invitation letter (including information on possible benefits and risks of screening) is sent to the person’s home address followed by the test kit.
    • Participants collect two samples from each of three separate bowel motions using the cardboard sticks provided. One of three flaps on the testing kit is peeled back for each bowel motion and a sample applied to each of the two exposed widows before resealing the window.
    • Once all six windows have been used, the kit must be returned (in the prepaid envelope) for analysis within 14 days of the first sample being taken.
    • Results are sent by letter to the person's home address within 2 weeks of the laboratory receiving the completed kit.
    • The GP is informed electronically.

[UK NSC, 2016; Koo, 2017; PHE, 2018; Cancer Research UK, 2019d]
